header_summary:
The SeedHammer team has proposed a new standard output descriptor for metal engraved backups, using PSBT binary encoding based on BIP174 and adhering to textual encoding standards from BIPs 380-386 and BIP 389. The proposed format emphasizes the use of wallet-policies for key references and excludes inline keys, while also incorporating metadata such as labels and birthdate blocks. SeedHammer is soliciting community feedback on their proposal, offering links for detailed examination, and is considering the formal BIP process.

A discussion has emerged within the blockchain community over the encoding method for the new standard, with Blockchain Commons advocating for CBOR due to its established nature and SeedHammer favoring PSBT for its simplicity and wallet integration. The possibility of creating a unique header and magic number or extending the existing PSBT format is being debated, with SeedHammer inviting constructive criticism on their approach.

In parallel, the community is addressing the imminent shutdown of the current mailing list by exploring alternative communication platforms. Google Groups, GitHub discussions, a new mailman instance, and a Discourse instance have all been considered, with varying concerns about subscription hurdles, moderation, and spam. A decision-making vote on the future platform is planned for the next meeting, and Matt Corallo has urged community members to contribute their views in the interim to ensure a broad representation of perspectives.

recent_posts.title: A proposal for a "PSBT for descriptors" format
recent_posts.summary:
- SeedHammer is developing a metal backup descriptor using PSBT binary encoding.
- The descriptor adheres to BIPs standards, supports Miniscript, and includes metadata.
- Debate exists between using CBOR or PSBT, with SeedHammer favoring the latter.

recent_posts.title: Mailing List Future
recent_posts.summary:
- The meeting addressed the mailing list's year-end shutdown and future platform options.
- Concerns arose over Google Groups access for non-Gmail users and GitHub's moderation tools.
- A vote on platform alternatives, like self-hosted Discourse, will follow at the next meeting.

active_posts.title: Ordinals BIP PR
active_posts.summary:
- The sender requests clarification and feedback on the nine-month-old Ordinals BIP PR.
- They highlight that BIPs serve as technical documentation without ensuring consensus.
- The sender seeks BIP editors' input on the suitability and scope of the ordinals BIP.

active_posts.title: Purely off-chain coin colouring
active_posts.summary:
- Casey Rodarmor proposed tracking satoshis for NFT creation without documenting data association.
- Inscriptions for satoshis can be stored off-chain, reducing costs and blockchain overhead.
- Liquid's multi-asset model may outperform NFTs for semi-fungibility and value alignment.

active_posts.title: HTLC output aggregation as a mitigation for tx recycling, jamming, and on-chain efficiency (covenants)
active_posts.summary:
- HTLC output aggregation creates chain-efficient outputs, resisting transaction recycling and slot jamming.
- This method combines all HTLCs into one output, allowing claim of individual parts based on preimage possession.
- Challenges include the need for new covenant primitives and solutions for high fee scenarios and limitations.

active_posts.title: Lightning Address in a Bolt 12 world
active_posts.summary:
- Proposed changes enhance privacy in the lightning address protocol by private domain linkage.
- Design includes DNS queries and optional methods for clients to acquire payment details.
- Feedback will refine proposals into a Bitcoin Improvement Proposal for protocol improvements.

active_posts.title: Liquidity Ads: Updated Spec Posted, please review
active_posts.summary:
- Liquidity Ads spec moved from CSV to CLTV for leasor fund locking, enhancing transaction security.
- Variable lease terms introduced, channel fee caps adjusted for commitment duration flexibility.
- Community input spurred finer channel fee increments and considers a fraud proof mechanism.

active_posts.title: HTLC output aggregation as a mitigation for tx recycling, jamming, and on-chain efficiency (covenants)
active_posts.summary:
- HTLC output aggregation enables efficient fee allocation and requires a covenant for implementation.
- Aggregated outputs combat slot jamming and may allow unlimited active HTLCs with economic feasibility.
- New covenant primitives and PTLCs are explored to address slot jamming and enhance channel efficiency.
